Subject: Re: [junit] How to test protected and private methods/ fields?

In response to Nic's specific example, I would suggest this is crying out 
for a Strategy design pattern.  In this case, the algorithm and any 
refinements would be represented by their own class and would therefore be 
testable in their own right.

I agree that a private method probably shouldn't need independent testing 
outside of the public/protected method(s) that call it, but I will 
typically use a protected method as a default implementation (eg. have an 
interface, then an abstract class that implements that interface with some 
default protected implementations, then a bunch of classes that extend the 
abstract class and override the methods they are interested in).  In this 
case, I do actually want to test the protected methods, and Matt's solution 
of test cases in the same package in a different directory seems an 
inherently elegant solution to this problem.

Still annoyed that I didn't know that about protected methods though :o)

Dan.


At 14:52 23/05/2001 +0100, you wrote:
>Jim Cheesman wrote:
>
> > At 02:20 PM 23/05/01, you wrote:
> > >So to answer the question about private/protected methods: Does a private
> > >method expose itself to external components? No - therefore we do not need
> > >to test them. Errors within private methods will become apparent from
> > >testing the other interfaces.
> >
> > Undoubtably that's true. But then if we are accepting that testing
> > public/friendly/protected methods adecuately test these methods, why not go
> > one step beyond and say that black box testing is all we need? It seems to
> > me that testing private methods is as useful and valid as testing
> > non-private ones, just at a different level of granularity.
>
>As a specific example, say I've got some computation that involves a fairly
>hairy algorithm in one place.  I probably want to encapsulate that algorithm
>into its own method so, e.g., I can Substitute in a new Algorithm later when
>someone points out that I (again) made the problem a lot harder than it needed
>to be.  I may well want to make that method private, though, as its existence
>or signature could reveal more about the internals of my class than I'd like;
>it might, e.g., have an argument that refers to a component of some (private)
>field.
>
>Presumably I would be _especially_ interested in testing such a method given
>that it represents a non-trivial algorithm.  If I'm forced to only test it
>indirectly then the tests of the public methods are likely to be harder to
>write and may depend in weird ways on this (hidden) implementation decision.
>
>I find that one of the (many) advantages of breaking things down into little
>methods is that writing the tests is both less difficult and less
>(psychologically) daunting.  Big methods with complex behaviors are a pain to
>test because there's so much _thinking_ involved in figuring out appropriate
>boundary conditions, blah, blah, blah, while little methods are usually much
>easier to test just because they're easier to understand.  The flipside,
>though, is (as has been mentioned before) I don't want the creation of these
>little (sub)methods to make my public class interface (and consequently my
>public obligations) bigger and more complex.  Thus I almost always make these
>new little methods private initially, and only change them to protected or
>public later when some clear need arises.  (As others have noted, this is
>essentially an application of YAGNI.)
>
>     Nic
